tit.e: Yabusame (shooting arrows from a galloping horse)
Yabusame (shooting arrows from a galloping horse)
Yabusame (shooting arrows from a galloping horse)

sen.j: 流鏑馬（やぶさめ）とは、疾走する馬上から的に鏑矢（かぶらや）を射る、日本の伝統的な騎射の技術・稽古・儀式のことを言う。
sen.e: Yabusame is the Japanese traditional skills, practice and rite to shoot whistling arrows from a running horse.
Yabusame is the traditional Japanese rite of shooting whistling arrows from a galloping horse.
Yabusame is the Japanese traditional skill, practice and rite of shooting whistling arrows from a galloping horse.
sen.cmt: 技術、稽古の部分を元に戻しました。NR: "traditional skills" should be "traditional skill".

sen.j: ウマを馳せながら矢を射ることから、「矢馳せ馬（やばせうま）」と呼ばれ、時代が下るにつれて「やぶさめ」と呼ばれるようになったといわれる。
sen.e: It is believed to have been called 'yabaseuma (shooting arrows from a galloping horse)' because arrows were shot from a running horse, and be called 'yabusame' as the time passed by.
It is believed to have been called 'yabaseuma because arrows were shot from a galloping horse, and over time was changed to 'yabusame.'
It is believed to have been called 'yabaseuma' because arrows were shot from a galloping horse, and over time was changed to 'yabusame.'
sen.cmt: OkNR: The closing quotation mark was missing.

sen.j: 『中右記』の永長元年（1096年）の項などに記されているように、馬上における実戦的弓術の一つとして平安時代から存在した。
sen.e: As described in the year 1096 section of Chuyuki (a diary written by FUJIWARA no Munetada), yabusame has existed since the Heian Era as one of fighting archery methods performed on horseback.
As described in the section dated 1096 of Chuyuki (a diary written by FUJIWARA no Munetada), yabusame has been practiced since the Heian Era as one of the fighting skills performed on horseback.
As described in the section of Chuyuki (a diary written by FUJIWARA no Munetada) dated 1096, yabusame has been practiced since the Heian period as a practical fighting skill performed on horseback.
sen.cmt: Moving "of Chuyuki (a diary written by FUJIWARA no Munetada)" next to section makes this read more naturally to me.Era→periodに変更しました。

sen.j: 鎌倉時代には「秀郷流」と呼ばれる技法も存在し、武士の嗜みとして、また幕府の行事に組み込まれたことも含めて盛んに稽古・実演された。
sen.e: There was a technique called 'the Hidesato school' in the Kamakura Era, and samurai enthusiastically had training of and demonstrated yabusame for their graces and also due to the inclusion of it in events planned by the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun.)

There was a technique called 'the school (style) of Hidesato' and samurai enthusiastically trained and demonstrated yabusame for their hobby and due to the inclusion of it in events planned by the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun.)There was a technique called 'the Hidesato style of yabusame taught at the Hidesato school and samurai enthusiastically trained and demonstrated it as a sport in events planned by the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun.)
sen.cmt: 田中さん: 以下、黄色のセルは翻訳者さんとチェッカーがやり取りしたコメントです。翻訳は最終版として修正されているはずです。revised for grammar and clarity, "graces" changed to "lords," but I'm not sure if this is the correct translation. I left my previous comments, above, as a reference for comparison. My comments on the "red" revisions are as follows: I don't see how "a school or school style:" is a technique? However a school could have "developed a technique." If "Hidesato" invented or developed the technique, then it could be called "the Hidesato technique of Yabusame." Shooting a bow and arrow from a horse is not a "hobby" in English, it could, however, be called a "sport" Please see the third revision I made in red, under the green highlighted text. However, I found no comments on "graces" by the translator. Has she suggested it be deleted?
sen.e: A technique known as 'the Hidesato-style of yabusame' was practiced during the Kamakura period, and samurai trained in this pastime enthusiastically, giving demonstrations at events organized by the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: "流"can also mean style rather than school, and this is what I have assumed is meant here as it seems to make more sense. You may want to check this.Please note that the period at the end of the sentence should be placed after the parentheses, not inside.The way I have rewritten this does deviate from the Japanese a little but it seems more likely to me that the samurai trained in this as a pastime and demonstrated it at events. To say that they demonstrated it as a hobby or sport (or pastime) sounds odd to me.

sen.j: だが、個人による騎射戦術が廃れた室町時代・安土桃山時代と、時を経るに従い一時廃れた。
sen.e: However, the fighting technique of individual's shooting arrows on horseback began to lose an importance as the time went by through the Muromachi Era and the Azuchi-Momoyama Era and became unpopular for a while.
However, yabusame began to lose importance during the Muromachi and Azuchi-Momoyama Eras and became unpopular for a while.
sen.cmt: reduced redundancy for clarity and readability
sen.e: However, yabusame began to lose importance during the Muromachi and Azuchi-Momoyama periods and became unpopular for a while.

sen.j: 江戸時代に入り享保9年(1724年)、時の征夷大将軍、徳川吉宗の命を受けた小笠原流20代小笠原貞政は、小笠原の伝書を研究し新たな流鏑馬制定、古式と共に奥勤めの武士達に流鏑馬、笠懸の稽古をつける。
sen.e: In the Edo Era, at the direction of the current shogun Yoshimune TOKUGAWA, Sadamasa OGASAWARA, the Ogasawara school's 20th head, developed a new style of yabusame after the studies of the Ogasawara's textbook, and gave training of the new yabusame and kasagake (shooting a bamboo hat) to samurai worriars serving backoffice work as well as the old style of yabusame.

In the Edo Era, at the direction of the shogun Yoshimune TOKUGAWA, Sadamasa OGASAWARA, the Ogasawara school's 20th principal, developed a new style of yabusame after the studiing the Ogasawara textbook, and trained samurai in the new form of yabusame and kasagake (shooting a bamboo hat) together with the older style of yabusame.
sen.cmt: revised to reduce redundancy, improve grammar and clarity
sen.e: In the Edo period of 1724, at the direction of the shogun Yoshimune TOKUGAWA, Sadamasa OGASAWARA, the Ogasawara school's 20th principal, developed a new style of yabusame after the studying the Ogasawara textbook, and trained samurai serving backoffice work in the new form of yabusame and kasagake (shooting a bamboo hat) together with the older style of yabusame.
sen.cmt: 「奥勤めの」の部分を加えました。Era→periodに変更しました。

sen.j: 享保13年（1728年）、徳川家重の世嗣ぎのために疱瘡治癒祈願として穴八幡宮北の高田馬場（現在の現在の東京都新宿区西早稲田三丁目）にて流鏑馬を執り行い、これを奉納した（この10年後、無事疱瘡祈願成就した折に報賽として再び行われ、その様子を絵巻にしたものが『流鏑馬絵巻』である）。
sen.e: To pray for the cure of a smallpox Ieshige TOKUGAWA was suffering, yabusame was performed at Takadanobaba (current address: 3-chome, Nishiwaseda, Shinjuku Ward, Tokyo) in dedication to Anahachiman-gu Shrine West in 1728 (yabusame was again performed there in ten years to appreciate the past visit when the pray for a complete cure came true, an emaki of which is called "Yabusame Emaki (the picture scroll of archery on horseback.)

As prayer ceremony for curing smallpox that Ieshige TOKUGAWA was suffering from, yabusame was performed at Takadanobaba (present day location at: 3-chome, Nishiwaseda, Shinjuku Ward, Tokyo) in a dedication to the Anahachiman-gu Shrine West in 1728 (yabusame was again performed there ten years later in appreciation of the complete cure that came about, an emaki of which is called "Yabusame Emaki (a picture scroll of archery on horseback.)

Yabusame was performed at Takadanobaba (present-day location: 3-chome, Nishiwaseda, Shinjuku Ward, Tokyo) in a dedication to the Anahachiman-gu Shrine North in 1728 as part of a prayer ceremony performed to cure Ieshige TOKUGAWA's heir of smallpox (yabusame was again performed there ten years later in appreciation of the complete cure that Ieshige's heir experienced, and an emaki (picture scroll) called "Yabusame Emaki" (a picture scroll depicting archery on horseback) was drawn to record the event).
sen.cmt: West→North「世継ぎ」の部分の訳を加えました。

sen.j: この後、将軍家の厄除け、誕生祈願の際などに度々流鏑馬が行われるようになる。
sen.e: Following the above, yabusame was often performed in the ceremonies of warding off evil in a shogun family, praying for the birth of children, etc.
In addition to the above, yabusame was often performed in ceremonies to ward off evil in a shogun family, and when praying for the birth of children, etc.
In addition to the above, yabusame was often performed in ceremonies to ward off evil in a shogun family, and when praying for the birth of children, etc.

sen.j: 明治維新を経て幕府解体、また第二次世界大戦と以後の煽りを受けるなど三度の衰退を見るが戦後に復興、現在に至る。
sen.e: With the dissolution of the bakufu (the Tokunaga shogunate), breakout of World War II and its aftermath, yabusame began to lose its importance three times, but it revived after the end of the war and remains at present.

With the dissolution of the bakufu (the Tokunaga shogunate), breakout of World War II and its aftermath, yabusame began to lose its importance for the third time, but it was revived after the end of the war and remains popular at present.

Despite losing popularity for a second time following the dissolution of the bakufu (the Tokugawa shogunate) that was brought about by the Meiji Restoration and for a third time following the outbreak of World War II and its immediate aftermath, yabusame experienced a revival after the end of the war and remains popular to this day.
sen.cmt: Tokunaga→Tokugawa「明治維新を経て」の部分の訳を加えました。

sen.j: 現在、流鏑馬は神社の神事として日本の各地で盛んに行われ、観光の目玉となっている。
sen.e: Currently, yabusame is actively performed in many local areas in Japan for a Shinto ritual, and takes a role of main attraction for tourism.
Currently, yabusame is actively performed in many local areas in Japan as a Shinto ritual, and is main attraction for tourist.
Currently, yabusame is actively performed in many local areas in Japan as a Shinto ritual, and is a main tourist attraction.
sen.cmt: grammar - “is main attraction for tourist” →“is a main tourist attraction”

tit.cmt: OKAs this is a heading the first word should be capitalized.

sen.j: 馬を疾走させる直線区間で、通常2町 (単位)（約218メートル）。
sen.e: A a straight course to gallop a horse is two cho (approximately 218 meter) long.
On the straight course, a horse gallops for two cho (approximately 218 meters).
On the straight course, a horse gallops for two cho (approximately 218 meters).

sen.j: 進行方向左手に間をおいて3つの的を立てる。
sen.e: On the left side along the running course, three targets are placed a certain distance apart.
On the left side along the run, three targets are placed a spedified distance apart.
On the left side along the run, three targets are placed a specified distance apart.

sen.j: 馬場から的までの距離は5m前後、的の高さは2m前後。
sen.e: Distance between the riding ground and targets is 5 meter apart and the targets are hung approximately 2 meter up.
The distance between the rider and the targets is about 5 meters and the targets are hung approximately 2 meter high..
The distance between the rider and the targets is about 5 meters and the targets are hung approximately 2 meter high.

sen.j: （流派や規定の違いによりそれぞれの距離にはばらつきがある）。
sen.e: (The distances vary according to the schools or the rules.)
(The distances vary according to the schools or the rules.)
(The distances vary according to the schools or the rules.)

sen.j: 射手（いて）は、狩装束をまとい、馬を疾走させ、連続して矢を射る。
sen.e: An archer who is dressed for hunting makes a horse rush and shoots arrows continuously.

An archer, dressed for hunting, makes his horse gallop while he shoots his arrows one after another. An archer, traditionally dressed, spurs his horse into a gallop while shooting his arrows one after another.
sen.cmt: "dressed for hunting" I wonder if "dressed for battle" would be more appropriate? Revised for clarity and readability.↓[From Translator]There was a set of clothing and equipment for going hunting at that time, I supose. So, the archer put on such gears to go hunting. Hunting what while on horseback? deer, wild boar on horseback? Hard to imagine what they would hunt on horseback in Japan with a bow and arrow? This may be so, however, mentioning hunting clothes in the context of a military "technique" or "sport"or "training exercise" seems to be misleading and out of place especially in a school that trains samurai for battle. There have been no previous mention of "hunting" in the context of this file and suddenly using "hunting" makes one wonder if it isn't a mistake, If might be less confusing to the reader if "hunting" is left out altogether and/or use a broader term like "traditional clothes" or "traditional please see my suggested third revision in red below the first one in black.
sen.e: An archer, dressed in hunting gear, spurs his horse into a gallop while shooting his arrows one after another.
sen.cmt: As the Japanese clearly says hunting gear, I think we're obliged to translate this but I do agree with the checker that it seems strange that a samurai would wear hunting gear to perform what is essentially a martial art. In this kind of situation, all we can really do is point out to the client that this seems a little odd.

tit.e: Three styles of archery on horseback
Three styles of archery on horseback
Three styles of archery on horseback

sen.j: 馬上における弓術には他に笠懸（かさがけ）や犬追物（いぬおうもの）があり、流鏑馬とあわせて「騎射三物」とされる。
sen.e: As other types of shooting arrows on horseback, there are the kasagake and inuoimono (shooting a dog), and these two and yabusame are collectively called 'three types of archery on horseback.'
Other types of archery practiced on horseback are kasagake and inuoimono (shooting a dog), and these two plus yabusame make up the 'three types.
sen.cmt: revised for clarity and correctness, redundancy reduced
sen.e: Other types of archery practiced on horseback are kasagake and inuoimono (shooting a dog), and these two plus yabusame make up the 'three types of archery on horseback.'
sen.cmt: 原文の意味が伝わるように補いました。

sen.j: 的と射手との距離を10～15間（約18～27メートル）に1つ置いたものを「笠懸」、竹垣で囲んだ馬場に150匹の犬を放して射手36騎が3手に分かれて犬を射るものを「犬追物」という。
sen.e: In the 'Kasagake', one target is placed 18 to 27 meter apart from the archer, and in the 'Inuoimono', 150 (a hundred and fifty) dogs are unleashed in a riding ground enclosed with a bamboo fence and shot by three groups of 36 (thirty six) archers.

In 'Kasagake', one target is placed 18 to 27 meters from the archer, and in the 'Inuoimono', 150 (a hundred and fifty) dogs are unleashed in a riding ground enclosed with a bamboo fence and shot by three groups of 36 (thirty six) archers.

In 'Kasagake', one target is placed 18 to 27 meters from the archer, and in the 'Inuoimono', 150 (a hundred and fifty) dogs are unleashed in a riding ground enclosed with a bamboo fence and shot by three groups of 36 (thirty six) archers.

sen.j: 犬追物では、犬を傷つけないよう「蟇目（ひきめ）」と呼ばれる大型の鏑をつけた矢を用いる。
sen.e: In the Inuoimono, an archer shoots arrows with a large kabura (the round tail of an arrow) called 'hikime' for the safety of the dogs.
In the Inuoimono, an archer shoots arrows that have a large kabura (round head on an arrow) called 'hikime' to protect the dogs from injury.
sen.cmt: revised for clarity, tail changed to head as in "arrowhead"
sen.e: In the Inuoimono, an archer shoots arrows that have a large kabura (round head on an arrow) called 'hikime' to protect the dogs from injury.

sen.j: 以下、徳川氏での例について述べる。
sen.e: Let's see the Tokugwa clan's riding ground for instance.
Let's take a look at the Tokugwa clan's riding grounds for example.
Let's take a look at the Tokugawa clan's riding grounds for example.

sen.j: 馬場は長さ2町である。
sen.e: The straight course is two cho (approximately 218 meter) long.
The straight course is two cho (approximately 218 meters) long.
The straight course is two cho (approximately 218 meters) long.

sen.j: 広さ2杖半ほどのなかに幅1杖の芝をはるか、または縄をはって、中に砂をまいて馬走とする。
sen.e: To make a basou (a track), a piece of land of approximately 2.5 jo (10 shaku per 1 jo. 7.5 shaku per 1 jo (in the past)) is partially covered by a lawn sheet of one jo in width or enclosed with ropes, and the enclosed area is covered with sand.
sen.cmt: 一丈(10尺であるが、古くは7尺5寸）という記載を見つけました。
sen.e: To make a basou (a running track), a land area measuring approximately 2.5 jo (10 shaku per 1 jo. 7.5 shaku per 1 jo) is planted with grass of one jo in width or another way is to frame the running track with rope and covered the area inside the rope frame with sand.
sen.cmt: revised, however, "lawn sheet" is not understood. Is this a sheet of canvas or other material that horses run on? Sounds strange and needs clarification↓[From Translator]The original Japanese is not enough to know the details of basou. I checked a few websites, but in vain. Does the revision make sense? I made another revision below the first. Since I'm not framiliar with the Japanese measurements used here, It is hard to picture the track except by imagining the length x width, for example in English... 300 meters by 6 meters, I can imagine the length vs the width. My understanding of the above revision is there are two ways to make a running track, one is by planting grass within the length and width of a marked running track, or by framing the running track with rope and filling the area inside the rope with sand.
sen.e: A basou (running track) can be made in one of two ways: by laying a strip of turf measuring about 1 jo (about 3 meters) in width inside a track measuring about 2.5 jo (about 7.5 meters) in width; or by running a length of rope along either side of the track and covering the area inside with sand.
sen.cmt: 文法、語句の意味など不自然なため全体を修正し直しました。

sen.j: いちだん掘り下げることもある。
sen.e: The land may be digged a little deeper to make a basou.
The land may be dug a little deeper to make the basou.
The land may be dug a little deeper to make the basou.

sen.j: 両側には埒がある。
sen.e: There are rachi (a fence) on the both ends of the basou.
There are rachi (fences) on the both sides of the basou.
There are rachi (fences) on the both sides of the basou.

sen.j: 左を男埒といい、高さは2尺3寸、右側は女埒といい、高さは2尺、木製でもあり、萩でもむすぶ。
sen.e: A rachi on the left side is called o-rachi (a fence on the man side) and two shaku three sun high, while a rachi on the right side is called me-rachi (a fence on the woman side) and 2 shaku high, and the rachi was made of wood and tied with bush clover, too.
sen.cmt: 「萩でもむすぶ」の意味が定かでなかったので、埒を萩で結んだと英訳しました。
sen.e: A rachi on the left side is called o-rachi (a fence on the man's side) and are two shaku three sun high, while a rachi on the right side is called me-rachi (a fence on the woman's side) and 2 shaku high, and the rachi was made of wood and also tied with bush clover,.

A rachi on the left side is called o-rachi (a fence on the man's side) and are two shaku three sun high, while a rachi on the right side is called me-rachi (a fence on the woman's side) and is 2 shaku high, and the rachi was made of wood and also tied with bush clover.
sen.cmt: 文法間違い。”and 2 shaku high;”→”and is 2 shaku high;”

sen.j: 的は3箇所にたてる。
sen.e: Targets are placed at three locations.
Targets are placed at three locations.
Targets are placed at three locations.

sen.j: 一の的までは48杖、一の的～二の的間は38杖、二の的～三の的間は37杖である。
sen.e: The first target is placed in 48 jo, the second target is placed 38 jo apart from the first target and the third target is placed 37 jo apart from the second target.
The first target is placed at 48 jo, the second target is placed 38 jo apart from the first target and the third target is placed 37 jo apart from the second target.
The first target is placed at 48 jo, the second target is placed 38 jo from the first target and the third target is placed 37 jo apart from the second target.

sen.j: 的と馬走との間は3杖であり、上手には5杖、7杖などに的をたてることもある。

The targets are placed 3 jo apart from the basou (track) and may be placed five jo or seven jo apart from the basou in the foreground.
The targets are placed 3 jo apart from the basou (track) and may be placed five jo or seven jo apart from the basou in the foreground.

sen.j: 的は方1尺8寸、厚さ1分ほどのヒノキ板である。
sen.e: The targets are a square in shape with a side of 1 shaku eight sun long and approximately 1 bu (3.3 miri meters) thick and made from hinoki (a Japanese cypress.)
The targets are square with sides of 1 shaku eight sun long and are approximately 1 bu (3.3 miri meters) thick and made from hinoki (a Japanese cypress.)
The targets are square with sides of 1 shaku eight sun long and are approximately 1 bu (3.3 milli meters) thick and made from hinoki (a Japanese cypress.)
sen.cmt: ミリ miri→milli チェックお願いします。

sen.j: 的串の長さは3尺5寸ほどで、的をはさみ、頂点を上下に（いわゆるダイヤ型に）たてる。
sen.e: A matogushi (a pole on which a target is hung) is three shaku five sun long, and two matogushi are placed to hold a target with its two corners upward and downward each (so-called, in a diamond shaped appearance.)
A matogushi (a pole on which a target is hung) is three shaku five sun long, and two matogushi are placed to hold a target with its two corners, one facing up and one down (in a diamond shape.)
A matogushi (a pole on which a target is hung) is three shaku five sun long, and two matogushi are placed to hold a target with its two corners, one facing up and one down (in a diamond shape.)

sen.j: 射手の服装は水干、または鎧直垂を着て、裾および袖をくくり、腰には行縢をつけ、あしに物射沓をはき、左に射小手をつけ、手袋をはめ、右手に鞭をとり、頭には綾藺笠をいただく。
sen.e: An archer wears a suikan or yoroi-hitatare with its bottom and sleeves tied, a mukabaki around his/her waist, a monoigutu on his feet, an ikote and glove on his left hand, a whip in his right hand and an ayaigasa on his head.

The archer wears a suikan or yoroi-hitatare with its bottom and sleeves tied, a mukabaki around his/her waist, a monoigutu on his feet, a ikote and glove on his left hand, a whip in his right hand and a ayaigasa on his head.

The archer wears a suikan or yoroi-hitatare with its bottom and sleeves tied, a mukabaki around his/her waist, a monoigutu on his feet, a ikote and glove on his left hand, a whip in his right hand and a ayaigasa on his head.

sen.j: 太刀を負い、刀をさし、鏑矢を5筋さした箙を負い、弓ならびに鏑矢1筋を左手に持つ。
sen.e: An archer carries a large sword and an ebira with five whistling arrows on his back, a sword in his waist belt and a bow and one suji in his left hand.
The archer carries a large sword and an ebira with five whistling arrows on his back, a sword in his waist belt and a bow and one suji in his left hand.
The archer carries a large sword and an ebira with five whistling arrows on his back, a sword in his waist belt and a bow and an arrow in his left hand.

sen.j: 次第は、射手、諸役ともに神拝がおわって馬場に行き、馬場をひととおり見て回り、射手は馬場末にあつまりならび、ウマを立て、諸役はそれぞれ所定の位置につく。
sen.e: Then, after archers and officials finish praying to God and go to the riding course to look around it, they gather at the end of the riding course and line up the horses, while the officials get to their places.

Then, after the archers and officials finish praying to God and go to the riding course to look around it, they gather at the end of the riding course and line up the horses, while the officials take their places.

Then, after the archers and officials finish praying to God and go to the riding course to look around it, they gather at the end of the riding course and line up the horses, while the officials take their places.

sen.j: 日記役が立ち出て、射手のなかから一番の射手がこれに出向かってひざまづくとき、日記役は「流鏑馬はじめませ」と宣する。
sen.e: After a secretary appears and the first archer kneels down in front of the secretary, the secretary declares 'you may start the yabusame demonstration.'
After the secretary appears and the first archer kneels down in front of the secretary, the secretary declares 'you may start the yabusame demonstration.'
After the secretary appears and the first archer kneels down in front of the secretary, the secretary declares 'you may start the yabusame demonstration.'

sen.j: この間、一同の射手は下馬する。
sen.e: During these procedures, other archers alight from the horses.
During these procedures, other archers alight from their horses.
During these procedures, other archers alight from their horses.

sen.j: 一番の射手がこれをうけて立ち帰り、射手に伝え、一同うちそろって乗馬し、馬場元に行き、扇形にウマを立てならぶ。
sen.e: The first archer is back to tell the declaration to other archers, and upon hearing, all archers ride a horse at once and go to the riding ground base and arrange the horses to make a fan-shape formation.
sen.cmt: 訳者注：馬場元の意味が不明でしたので、調査しましたが分かりませんでした。一応、baseと英訳しました。
sen.e: The first archer returns to report the declaration to other archers, and upon hearing this, all archers mount their horses at once and go to the riding grounds and arrange the horses in a fan-shaped formation.

The first archer returns to report the declaration to other archers, and upon hearing this, all archers mount their horses at once and go to the riding grounds and arrange the horses in a fan-shaped formation.

sen.j: 一番の射手がまずウマをすすめて立ち出、祝詞を奏し、おわって中啓を出し、扇捌きをなし、そのままウマを馳せ出し、中啓を前方にたかく投げ揚げ、取りかけて一の的を射る。
sen.e: After the first archer advances his horse, says a Shinto ritual prayer and takes out a chukei (a sort of fan) to perform 'ogihaki (motions with the chukei)', the archer starts galloping a horse and throws the chukei high forward and hits the first target, trying to catch the chukei.

After the first archer advances his horse, he says a Shinto ritual prayer and then takes out a chukei (a sort of fan) to perform 'ogihaki (motions with the chukei)', the archer starts a gallop and throws the chukei high and forward and hits the first target, then trying to catch the chukei.

After the first archer advances his horse, he says a Shinto ritual prayer and then takes out a chukei (a sort of fan) to perform 'ogihaki (motions with the chukei)', the archer starts his gallop and throws the chukei high and forward and hits the first target, then trying to catch the chukei.

sen.j: これを揚扇という。
sen.e: This is called Ageogi.
This is called Ageogi.
This is called Ageogi.

sen.j: ついで二の的、三の的を射ることはかわらない、射手つぎつぎと射おわり、
sen.e: The archer continues to hit all targets including the second and third ones and the other archers repeat the same process.
The archer continues to hit all the targets including the second and third ones and the other archers repeat the same process.
The archer continues to hit all the targets including the second and third ones and the other archers repeat the same process.

sen.j: 5騎でも7騎でも、当日最後の射手は老練、上手のものがこれにあたり、まず一の的を射て矢番いし、ただちに右手に鞭をとり、たかくさしあげしずかにこれをおろして取りかけ二の的を射、三の的のまえにも鞭をあげる。
sen.e: After the most experienced veteran archer from among five, seven or even more archers finish the yatsugai (fixing an arrow) just after shooting the first target, the archer grabs a whip in his right hand, raises it high and put it down gently, shoots the second target, and raise the whip before shooting the third target.

After the most experienced veteran archer from among five, seven, or even more archers finish the yatsugai (fixing an arrow) just after shooting the first target, the archer grabs a whip in his right hand, raises it high and puts it down gently, shoots the second target, and raises the whip before shooting the third target.

The most skillful veteran archer of the five, seven, or even more archers participating that day goes last, finishing the event by performing the following technique: first, he shoots the first target and fixes an arrow to his bow; immediately after this, he takes his whip in his right hand, raises it high, lowers it gently, and then shoots the second target; and finally, he fixes another arrow to his bow, raises his whip high, lowers it gently, and then shoots the third target.
sen.cmt: The Japanese doesn't actually say whether the archer fixes a new arrow to his bow, raises his whip, lowers it, and then shoots the target. It could be read as meaning that as this is the last ride of the day, the archer simply raises his whip in front of the third target without shooting.

sen.j: これを揚鞭といい、はなはだ困難な技術である。
sen.e: This is called Agemuchi and an extremely difficult technique.

This is called Agemuchi and is an extremely difficult technique to perform.

sen.j: 射手は射おわったものから馬場元にあつまるから、全部終了のときはただちに乗り出して、諸役はそれぞれの位置について支度所にもどる。
sen.e: The archers meet at the riding course base after each hitting, and upon completion of all hitting, all archers leave the spot and other officials get back to their position and go back to their office.

sen.e: Just after kicking a horse to start, an archer stands up putting his feet in the stirrups and spreading his right and left knees, which is called kuramawari, in order to keep three sun space between his body and a saddle.

sen.cmt: I'm not sure this is correct terminology… "attendant horse" or "horse attendant" the first describes a "horse" the second example describes "attendant" which is it?↓[From Translator]I read the explanation about "otomo uma" in Japanese which is displayed on the website, but it's complicate to summarize. The English (an attendant horse) should be deleted, because there is no Japanese corresponding to the English in the original context. I pasted a second revision in "red" below the first revision with both (Imabari City) and (an attendant horse) deleted. Also, I would suggest not using parenthesis, when the text can be included in the sentence without parenthesis. Also, the meaning here is still strange as "yabusame is performed for a horse" (the horse is watching the yabusame?) Should this be "yabusame is performed on horseback"? See third revision also in red.
